reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s formal benchmarking move: defining “best feasible future” via the 99.99th percentile of a “well‑informed” probability distribution, then setting eutopia/mostly-great as fractions of that. This matters because later fussiness/rarity talk is partly framed relative to that benchmark and to likelihood under a default distribution. However, the paper’s core thrust (many independent moral dimensions; fussy value functions; fragility) can largely be restated with alternative benchmarks (e.g., ‘best physically/technologically feasible’ or ‘best in some reference class’) without collapsing, so centrality is moderate, not high. Strength is moderate-low: the critique shows the percentile definition is distribution-relative and mixes feasibility with probability, which introduces ambiguity and can shift thresholds under different priors, but it doesn’t strongly refute the substantive claim that near-best futures are narrow/hard—it mainly pressures the objectivity/interpretation of the formalization. Most claims in the critique are correct (distribution relativity, unspecified credences, feasibility/probability conflation), and it’s clearly stated with little extraneous material and a single focus.
title: The percentile-based benchmark conflates feasibility with probability under unspecified priors
